SENT.plain: Beckwith-Wiedemann Syndrome (BWS) is the most common overgrowth syndrome in infancy
The characteristic findings are macroglossia, abdominal wall defects, and macrosomia
Genetic studies in infants with BWS demonstrate 3 major subgroups of patients: familial, sporadic, or chromosomally abnormal
Recognition in the neonatal period is important because of the high incidence of childhood malignant tumors associated with BWS
This article provides an overview of the syndrome and discusses its etiology, physical findings, and diagnostic evaluation
Management and clinical implications including family support will also be discussed
